description: Kathmandu Durbar Square is a UNESCO World Heritage Site located about two kilometers from the thermal area and a 10 to 15 minutes drive depending on the traffic. The entire area is dotted with temples, palaces, and towers that are very beautiful. Some are seriously damaged by the recent earthquake and are being restored, but few temples are functional. The square has access to several hotels and restaurants.
fun_fact: The Kumari, or living goddess, who is considered to be an incarnation of the goddess Taleju, resides in the Kumari Ghar built in 1757 by King Jayaprakash Malla.

description: Kathmandu Durbar Square is located in the heart of capital Kathmandu. It is one of the three durbar squares in the capital, the other being Patan Durbar Square and Bhaktapur Durbar Square. Unlike the other two durbar squares, this one served as the home for the kings of our country Nepal. After the unification, a big palace was built within the area for the kings to live in, but as of now it serves as a museum. Kathmandu Durbar Square is often known as a place where different kings ruled our country for generations. It is also a home to the living goddess Kumari. The area is a host to a lot of interesting local festivals throughout the year, with Indra Jatra being one of the very well-known festivals that goes on for a week straight.
fun_fact: The current Kumari is just about 6 years of age.

cultural_activities.description: A well-known festival that goes on for a week straight.

historical_events.description: Most of the temples and monuments were partially or completely damaged during the earthquake.
A significant historical event after which a big palace was built for the kings.

description: Kathmandu Durbar Square was one of the three Durbar (royal palace) squares in Kathmandu valley which was the significant identity of spectacular architectures rich in Newari culture. The durbar square was built at the time of Lichhavi Kings and underwent various renovations and new addition till Shah Dynasty. Though there are no written archives stating the history of Kathmandu Durbar Square, construction of the palace in the square is credited to Sankharadev (1069 –1083). As the first king of the independent Kathmandu City, Ratna Malla is said to have built the Taleju temple in the Northern side of the palace in 1501. The oldest temples in the square are those built by Mahendra Malla (1560 –1574). They are the temples of Jagannath, Kotilingeswara Mahadev, Mahendreswara, and the Taleju Temple. This three-roofed Taleju Temple was established in 1564, in a typical Newari architectural style and is elevated on platforms that form a pyramid-like structure. In the time of Pratap Malla, son of Laksminar Simha, the square was extensively developed. The square had undergone lot of changes and unplanned urbanization in the recent decades which has made this city over populated and over polluted.

condition.status: The massive earthquake has damaged most of its part. The tallest temple standing nine-stepped tall is no more left and the museum has been completely destroyed.

historical_events.event_description: There was several effect on Durbar square after 1934 earthquake. The temples such as Kageshwara temple which was built by daughter-in-law of Pratap Malla was beautiful temple of Newari architecture. After it was damaged in 1934 earthquake, the roof was replaced by a plain tin roof which was no near to Newari architecture.
The massive earthquake has damaged most of its part. The tallest temple standing nine-stepped tall is no more left and the museum has been completely destroyed.

description:
Kathmandu Durbar Square was one of the three Durbar (royal palace) squares in Kathmandu valley which was the significant identity of spectacular architectures rich in Newari culture. The durbar square was built at the time of Lichhavi Kings and underwent various renovations and new addition till Shah Dynasty.

Though there are no written archives stating the history of Kathmandu Durbar Square, construction of the palace in the square is credited to Sankharadev (1069 –1083). As the first king of the independent Kathmandu City, Ratna Malla is said to have built the Taleju temple in the Northern side of the palace in 1501. Construction of the Karnel Chok is not clearly stated in any historical inscriptions; although, it is probably the oldest among all the courtyards in the square. The Bhagavati Temple, originally known as a Narayan Temple, rises above the mansions surrounding it and was added during the time of Jagajaya Malla in the early eighteenth century.

The oldest temples in the square are those built by Mahendra Malla (1560 –1574). They are the temples of Jagannath, Kotilingeswara Mahadev, Mahendreswara, and the Taleju Temple. This three-roofed Taleju Temple was established in 1564, in a typical Newari architectural style and is elevated on platforms that form a pyramid-like structure.

In the time of Pratap Malla, son of Laksminar Simha, the square was extensively developed. He was an intellectual, a pious devotee, and especially interested in arts. Immediately after his coronation as a king, he immediately began enlargements to his royal palace, and rebuilt some old temples and constructed new temples, shrines and stupas around his kingdom. He added Nasal chowk, Mohan chowk and several other temples to enhance the beauty of the city and durbar square.

After the death of Pratap Malla, there was not much effort made by any other ruler in terms of cultural development. Later around 1692, Radhilasmi, the widowed queen of Pratap Malla, erected the tall temples of Shiva known as Maju Deval near the Garuda image in the square. This temple stands on nine stepped platforms and is one of the tallest buildings in the square.

There were several effects on Durbar square after the 1934 earthquake. The temples such as Kageshwara temple which was built by daughter-in-law of Pratap Malla was beautiful temple of Newari architecture. After it was damaged in 1934 earthquake, the roof was replaced by a plain tin roof which was no near to Newari architecture.

In this way Kathmandu Durbar square has undergone various changes and modifications. The massive earthquake has damaged most of its part. The tallest temple standing nine-stepped tall is no more left and the museum has been completely destroyed.

threats: Deterioration due to lack of proper maintenance

historical_events.event_description: Ratna Malla is said to have built the Taleju temple in the Northern side of the palace.
The Bhagavati Temple was added during the time of Jagajaya Malla.

historical_events.event_description: The oldest temples in the square are those built by Mahendra Malla. They are the temples of Jagannath, Kotilingeswara Mahadev, Mahendreswara, and the Taleju Temple.

historical_events.event_name: Development of the Square by Pratap Malla
historical_events.event_description: In the time of Pratap Malla, son of Laksminar Simha, the square was extensively developed. He added Nasal chowk, Mohan chowk and several other temples to enhance the beauty of the city and durbar square.
Radhilasmi, the widowed queen of Pratap Malla, erected the tall temples of Shiva known as Maju Deval near the Garuda image in the square.
There were several effects on Durbar square after the 1934 earthquake. The temples such as Kageshwara temple were damaged.
The massive earthquake has damaged most of its part. The tallest temple standing nine-stepped tall is no more left and the museum has been completely destroyed.

description:
Kathmandu Durbar Square was one of the three Durbar (royal palace) squares in Kathmandu valley which was the significant identity of spectacular architectures rich in Newari culture. The durbar square was built at the time of Lichhavi Kings and underwent various renovations and new addition till Shah Dynasty.

Though there are no written archives stating the history of Kathmandu Durbar Square, construction of the palace in the square is credited to Sankharadev (1069 –1083). As the first king of the independent Kathmandu City, Ratna Malla is said to have built the Taleju temple in the Northern side of the palace in 1501. Construction of the Karnel Chok is not clearly stated in any historical inscriptions; although, it is probably the oldest among all the courtyards in the square. The Bhagavati Temple, originally known as a Narayan Temple, rises above the mansions surrounding it and was added during the time of Jagajaya Malla in the early eighteenth century. The Narayan idol within the temple was stolen so Prithvi Narayan Shah replaced it with an image of Bhagavati, completely transforming the name of the temple.

The oldest temples in the square are those built by Mahendra Malla (1560 –1574). They are the temples of Jagannath, Kotilingeswara Mahadev, Mahendreswara, and the Taleju Temple. This three-roofed Taleju Temple was established in 1564, in a typical Newari architectural style and is elevated on platforms that form a pyramid-like structure
In the time of Pratap Malla, son of Laksminar Simha, the square was extensively developed. He was an intellectual, a pious devotee, and especially interested in arts. Immediately after his coronation as a king, he immediately began enlargements to his royal palace, and rebuilt some old temples and constructed new temples, shrines and stupas around his kingdom. He added Nasal chowk, Mohan chowk and several other temples to enhance the beauty of the city and durbar square.
After the death of Pratap Malla, there was not much effort made by any other ruler in terms of cultural development. Later around 1692, Radhilasmi, the widowed queen of Pratap Malla, erected the tall temples of Shiva known as Maju Deval near the Garuda image in the square. This temple stands on nine stepped platforms and is one of the tallest buildings in the square.
There was several effect on Durbar square after 1934 earthquake. The temples such as Kageshwara temple which was built by daughter-in-law of Pratap Malla was beautiful temple of Newari architecture. After it was damaged in 1934 earthquake, the roof was replaced by a plain tin roof which was no near to Newari architecture.
In this way Kathmandu Durbar square has undergone various changes and modifications. The massive earthquake has damaged most of its part. The tallest temple standing nine-stepped tall is no more left and the museum has been completely destroyed.

threats: Deterioration of original Newari architecture due to renovations

historical_events.event_description: Construction of the palace in the square is credited to Sankharadev (1069 –1083).
Ratna Malla is said to have built the Taleju temple in the Northern side of the palace.
The Bhagavati Temple was added during the time of Jagajaya Malla.
The oldest temples in the square are those built by Mahendra Malla (1560 –1574). They are the temples of Jagannath, Kotilingeswara Mahadev, Mahendreswara, and the Taleju Temple.
In the time of Pratap Malla, son of Laksminar Simha, the square was extensively developed.
Radhilasmi, the widowed queen of Pratap Malla, erected the tall temples of Shiva known as Maju Deval near the Garuda image in the square.
There was several effect on Durbar square after 1934 earthquake.
The massive earthquake has damaged most of its part. The tallest temple standing nine-stepped tall is no more left and the museum has been completely destroyed.

description: Kathmandu Durbar Square was one of the three Durbar (royal palace) squares in Kathmandu valley which was the significant identity of spectacular architectures rich in Newari culture. The durbar square was built at the time of Lichhavi Kings and underwent various renovations and new addition till Shah Dynasty. Though there are no written archives stating the history of Kathmandu Durbar Square, construction of the palace in the square is credited to Sankharadev (1069 –1083). As the first king of the independent Kathmandu City, Ratna Malla is said to have built the Taleju temple in the Northern side of the palace in 1501. The oldest temples in the square are those built by Mahendra Malla (1560 –1574). They are the temples of Jagannath, Kotilingeswara Mahadev, Mahendreswara, and the Taleju Temple. This three-roofed Taleju Temple was established in 1564, in a typical Newari architectural style and is elevated on platforms that form a pyramid-like structure. In the time of Pratap Malla, son of Laksminar Simha, the square was extensively developed. The major temples and shrines built in the square by Pratap Malla are Mohan chowk, Nasal chowk, Degutale Temple, Taleju Temple, and Krishna Temple. After the death of Pratap Malla, there was not much effort made by any other ruler in terms of cultural development. In this way Kathmandu Durbar squ are has undergone various changes and modifications.

threats: Deterioration due to lack of maintenance

historical_events.event_description: The earthquake is also known as Great Nepal Bihar Earthquake, occurred at around 2pm. The 8.4 Richter Earthquake killed 8519 people, destroyed 80893 buildings and severely damaged 126355 more houses.

Nepal was hit by 7.9 magnitude earthquake making Barpak of Gorkha as its epicenter devastating Kathmandu and its other peripheral districts (Lamjung, Sindhupalchowk , Dhading, Nuwakot, Kavre, Lamjung and Sankhu). Devastation got more serious after the 6.7 magnitude aftershock in the next day of the major earthquake. The death tolls have raised upto 8,786 dead in Nepal (officially) and 8,947 in total 21,952 injured (officially). Over 2 and half lakhs household was destroyed.

description: Kathmandu Durbar Square was one of the three Durbar (royal palace) squares in Kathmandu valley which was the significant identity of spectacular architectures rich in Newari culture. The durbar square was built at the time of Lichhavi Kings and underwent various renovations and new addition till Shah Dynasty. Though there are no written archives stating the history of Kathmandu Durbar Square, construction of the palace in the square is credited to Sankharadev (1069 –1083). As the first king of the independent Kathmandu City, Ratna Malla is said to have built the Taleju temple in the Northern side of the palace in 1501. The oldest temples in the square are those built by Mahendra Malla (1560 –1574). They are the temples of Jagannath, Kotilingeswara Mahadev, Mahendreswara, and the Taleju Temple. This three-roofed Taleju Temple was established in 1564, in a typical Newari architectural style and is elevated on platforms that form a pyramid-like structure. In the time of Pratap Malla, son of Laksminar Simha, the square was extensively developed. The square had undergone various changes and modifications. The massive earthquake has damaged most of its part.

Nepal was hit by 7.9 magnitude earthquake making Barpak of Gorkha as its epicenter devastating Kathmandu and its other peripheral districts.
